word.entryDescription: clothes you wear in bed when you sleep
word.entryExample: I put on my pyjamas before I go to bed.

word.entryDescription: something you gain as a result of passing an examination or successfully completing a course
word.entryExample: I got my coaching qualifications last year.

word.entryDescription: 15 minutes (to/past a time)
word.entryExample: It's a quarter to five.

word.entryDescription: a woman who rules a country or a king's wife
word.entryExample: Can we meet the queen in London?

word.entryDescription: something that someone asks you when they want information
word.entryExample: Are you ready to answer the next question?

word.entryDescription: a line of people or vehicles waiting for something
word.entryExample: She was the first in the queue.

word.entryDescription: to form or join a line of people or vehicles waiting for something
word.entryExample: If we buy our tickets online we won't have to queue!
Sam is a quick runner.

word.entryDescription: in a fast way
word.entryExample: Come here quickly and look at this.

word.entryDescription: making little or no sound
word.entryExample: I live in a quiet street.

word.entryDescription: in a way which does not make a lot of sound
word.entryExample: She speaks very quietly.

word.entryDescription: rather close, relatively close
word.entryExample: The fire came quite close to them, and for a while they were in a highly dangerous situation.

word.entryDescription: a small furry animal with long ears and a short bushy tail, often kept for food or as a pet
word.entryExample: Rabbits like to jump.

word.entryDescription: a competition in which you try to finish faster than the others
word.entryExample: Let's watch the race on TV.

word.entryDescription: another spelling of 'racket' – a piece of equipment used to hit a ball in tennis, squash, etc that consists of a handle and a round frame with a tight net inside
word.entryExample: When Maria plays tennis, she needs to bring her racquet and plenty of balls.

word.entryDescription: a metal device usually attached to a wall which is used to heat a room
word.entryExample: If you are cold put on the radiator.

word.entryDescription: new and different from usual
word.entryExample: A more radical solution would be to change our attitude to consumption and use less of everything the first place.

word.entryDescription: the railway system
word.entryExample: The American rail system covers 46 states and 35,000 km.

word.entryDescription: the tracks that a train runs on, or the whole train system
word.entryExample: They built a lot of railways in the 19th century.

word.entryDescription: drops of water that fall from clouds
word.entryExample: Is there a lot of rain in your country?

word.entryDescription: boots you wear to protect you from the rain
word.entryExample: You need rain boots today. It's wet outside.

word.entryDescription: a curve of several colours that can be seen in the sky when there is both sun and rain at the same time
word.entryExample: Look! There's a rainbow in the sky.

word.entryDescription: a coat you wear to protect you from the rain
word.entryExample: Take your raincoat with you – it's raining!

word.entryDescription: the amount of rain that falls on an area in a particular period of time; an occasion when rain falls
word.entryExample: A tropical climate is characterised by hot and humid weather, and there is heavy rainfall all year round.

word.entryDescription: a thick forest in a tropical area where it rains a lot
word.entryExample: The rainforest is home to some amazing animals.

word.entryDescription: when it is rainy there is rain falling from the sky
word.entryExample: On rainy days we stay indoors.

word.entryDescription: to improve the quality or standard of something
word.entryExample: To protect the natural world, it’s important to raise awareness of endangered species.

word.entryDescription: very uncommon or unusual
word.entryExample: Tourists to the Greek islands are educated about the rare seal.

word.entryDescription: an area of skin that becomes red, often spotty, and itchy or sore
word.entryExample: If a bee stings me, I get a rash and I start to itch.

word.entryDescription: fairly; quite
word.entryExample: Isn't this dress rather short?

word.entryDescription: not cooked or processed
word.entryExample: Animals have no choice but to eat raw food, but people can choose what and how they eat.

word.entryDescription: to get to or touch a place or point
word.entryExample: They fly over France and Spain until they reach the Rock of Gibraltar.

word.entryDescription: to look at words or symbols in a book and understand what they mean
word.entryExample: The teacher asked the students to read the book for homework.

word.entryDescription: to read and say words that are written down, so that people can hear
word.entryExample: I realized he hadn't read out my name.

word.entryDescription: an activity in which you read a book, magazine, newspaper, etc
word.entryExample: I go to the library often because I love reading.

word.entryDescription: prepared for what is going to happen
word.entryExample: When your pens are ready, you can start the test.

word.entryDescription: true in your mind or in the world and not false
word.entryExample: Is that real fur?

word.entryDescription: to look after a person or animal until they are fully grown
word.entryExample: Until the 19th Century, most people in Britain used to eat food that had been grown or reared locally, or caught in the sea.

word.entryDescription: why something exists, happens or is done
word.entryExample: Give me one good reason why we shouldn't buy this house.

word.entryDescription: (of prices) not too high
word.entryExample: This strap is made of leather and its price is very reasonable.

word.entryDescription: a piece of paper which shows that something has been paid for
word.entryExample: Don't forget to take your receipt if you want to get a refund.

word.entryDescription: the place at a hotel, guesthouse, etc where you go first when you arrive
word.entryExample: Please leave your key at the reception desk.

word.entryDescription: somebody who works at the front desk of an office or hotel, and helps people who arrive
word.entryExample: Can you tell me about your new job as a receptionist?

word.entryDescription: the instructions on how to prepare a food and a list of the ingredients needed
word.entryExample: Migrants coming to Britain over the last 50 years or so have brought their recipes with them, and introduced new flavours.

word.entryDescription: to know someone or something because of past experience
word.entryExample: To recognise someone's emotions is to understand how they are feeling.

word.entryDescription: when people show that they admire or are grateful for something
word.entryExample: Facial recognition helps us know our enemies.

word.entryDescription: to say that something is suitable or good when giving advice
word.entryExample: I would recommend this film to anyone.

word.entryDescription: an official suggestion about the best thing to do
word.entryExample: She was waiting for her doctor's reccomendation.

word.entryDescription: (= vinyl) a round flat piece of plastic with a hole in the middle that music and sound are stored on
word.entryExample: They made their first record in 1962.

word.entryDescription: to store information, music, film, etc on paper, on tape, on a disk, etc
word.entryExample: Tim records audio for books in the studio.
